electionAnalysisElectoralSystemsInNepal.response: I support the logic put forth by the Political Science (Coalition Theory) forecaster, particularly their emphasis on the high barriers presented by Nepal's consensus-driven coalition politics and the role of elite veto points. They correctly note that the parliamentary system's structure in Nepal disfavors outsider figures unless there is strong coalition-building, especially during a transitional crisis where the institutional environment leans heavily toward technocratic or compromise caretakers. The assessment that Lamichhane would require not just public support but also elite and cross-factional buy-in to become PM is accurate: in the current climate, even mass movements have channeled their demands through established or consensus figures (like Karki) rather than polarizing or legally compromised individuals. The forecaster also rightly quantifies the probability as low but nonzero, covering tail-risk scenarios, without overstating the likelihood of disruptive 'revolutionary' outcomes. I agree that the path to the premiership for someone with Lamichhane’s baggage requires not only elite acquiescence (which is clearly absent) but also drastic further destabilization that is not in evidence. The slight nonzero probabilities offered by some—rooted only in hypothetical tail-risk events like sudden collapse of consensus or mass-movement-driven rupture—do not present any new evidence, nor additional credible likelihood that Lamichhane could overcome the confluence of legal, institutional, and coalition hurdles by Jan 1, 2026. Since no new scenario or overlooked factor was uncovered that would meaningfully increase his odds, I see no reason to alter my initial estimate.

question_details.title: Who will be the next non-caretaker prime minister of Nepal? (Rabi Lamichhane)
question_details.description:
The Federal: [Who could be Nepal's next prime minister? Here are 5 top contenders](https://thefederal.com/category/international/nepals-next-prime-minister-after-olis-controversial-exit-206263)

> Scuffles were reported among Gen-Z factions backing different contenders outside the Nepal Army headquarters in Kathmandu on Wednesday evening, as talks to pick an interim leader after the violent overthrow of the government extended into the third day.

> KP Sharma Oli resigned as prime minister on Tuesday, leaving the post vacant while the anti-corruption revolt continues without a clear leader.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'Rabi Lamichhane'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question resolves as **Yes** for the individual who, after September 11, 2025 and before January 1, 2026 takes the [oath](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s852) of office and secrecy as the new [Prime Minister of Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Nepal) and wins a vote of confidence in the House of Representatives as required by [section 76](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Nepal_2016#s795) of the Constitution of Nepal. The question resolves as **No** for everyone else. If none of the listed candidates fulfills the criteria during that time period, then the question resolves as **No** for every option.
question_details.fine_print: This is a Group question, so you do not have to assess probabilities for every option. More options may be added after the question opens, if there is [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) reporting that a particular individual has a material probability of coming the next PM of Nepal.

**Gen Z's Gambit: Can Nepal's New Prime Minister Deliver?**
The article reports that the Sushila Karki‑led interim government, formed after the Gen Z revolution, has a six‑month mandate to hold elections. It warns that if elections cannot be organized within that period, Nepal could descend into a grave political and constitutional crisis. The article states, 'If elections cannot be organized in six months, Nepal could descend into a grave political and constitutional crisis.' Karki’s government has the support of the Gen Z movement but faces challenges from the three major parties— Nepali Congress, CPN‑UML, and CPN‑Maoist Centre—whose leaders (Sher Bahadur Deuba, KP Sharma Oli, Pushpa Kamal Dahal) remain in power. It notes that President Ramchandra Paudel dissolved Parliament, and that the Rastriya Swatantra Party’s leader Rabi Lamichhane is behind bars. The article highlights security concerns, citing 72 deaths during the Gen Z protests and the police’s failure to manage demonstrations. International partners India, China and the U.S. have welcomed the new government, but the article suggests that a tilt toward any of them could invite meddling. It concludes that if Karki can overcome these obstacles and hold elections by the proposed March 5, 2026 date, she would serve the country well; otherwise, a crisis could ensue.

**Prime Minister of Nepal Resigns Amid Massive Protests**
Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli resigned on September 15, 2025, amid violent protests that left at least 19 people dead and hundreds injured. The demonstrations, led by Generation Z, escalated when thousands tried to storm Parliament and government offices, burning former leaders' residences and demanding an end to endemic corruption in Oli's communist regime. Police responded with live fire, tear gas and water cannons, creating chaos in Kathmandu, a curfew was imposed and the army was deployed. Oli, who had been in power since July 2024, stepped down after the assault on his office, citing the failure of communist regimes to respond to popular demands without repression. 'Al Jazeera reporta que los manifestantes, inspirados en movimientos globales, rechazan la prohibición de redes sociales impuesta para censurar críticas', highlighting the hypocrisy of a government that preaches equality but enriches an elite. International groups such as Amnesty International condemn the excessive use of force, while former U.S. President Trump has called for global pressure against such authoritarian governments.

**Nepal PM Sushila Karki appoints three new ministers for interim cabinet**
On September 15 2025, the Hindustan Times reported that Nepal President Ramchandra Paudel swore in three ministers—Kulman Ghising, Rameshwor Khanal and Om Prakash Aryal—appointed by caretaker Prime Minister Sushila Karki for her newly formed cabinet. The oath ceremony took place at the President's Office, Sheetal Niwas, Maharajgunj, after which all three ministers immediately assumed their posts. Khanal, the former finance secretary, was sworn in as finance minister. Ghising, the former managing director of the Nepal Electricity Authority, was given charge of energy, water resources and irrigation; physical infrastructure and transport; and urban development. Aryal, an advocate, was appointed minister for home affairs and for law, justice and parliamentary affairs. The article notes that Karki, 73, became Nepal's first female prime minister on September 12, at the recommendation of the agitating 'Gen Z' group, to lead a caretaker government tasked with conducting fresh elections on March 5 2026. It also recounts that former Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned after widespread anti‑government protests led by the 'Gen Z' group against a social media ban and corruption allegations; the protests turned violent, with at least 72 people losing their lives in the nationwide unrest.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 15, 2025 09:23 AM
Source:[Hindustan Times](https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/nepal-pm-sushila-karki-appoints-three-new-ministers-for-interim-cabinet-101757927752490.html)

**Three ministers inducted by Nepal's new caretaker PM Karki sworn in**
On September 15 2025, the Business Standard reported that Nepal President Ramchandra Paudel administered the oath of office to three ministers—Kulman Ghising, Rameshwor Khanal, and Om Prakash Aryal—inducted by the newly appointed caretaker Prime Minister Sushila Karki. The swearing‑in ceremony took place at the President's Office, Sheetal Niwas, Maharjgunj, and the ministers assumed their respective portfolios: Khanal as Finance Minister; Ghising as Minister for Energy, Water Resources and Irrigation, Physical Infrastructure and Transport, and Urban Development; and Aryal as Minister for Home Affairs and for Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs. The article notes that Karki, 73, is the Himalayan nation's first woman prime minister and that she assumed office on Sunday, following the resignation of former PM K P Sharma Oli after widespread protests that left at least 72 people dead. The caretaker government, appointed at the recommendation of an agitating 'Gen Z' group, is mandated to conduct fresh elections on March 5 2026. The article also cites the headline 'Those involved in violence will face justice' as a statement from PM Karki.

**Sushila Karki to lead Nepal as interim PM, tasked with conducting fresh polls**
Former chief justice Sushila Karki will be sworn in as Nepal’s interim prime minister on Friday at 9 pm, becoming the country’s first woman to hold the post, according to the president’s office. The decision follows inconclusive talks between President Ramchandra Paudel, Gen‑Z protest representatives and the army. Karki, who has no party affiliation and a strong anti‑corruption record, was suggested by the protesters and will lead a caretaker government that will address their demands and organise fresh elections. She was born in Biratnagar in 1952, holds degrees in political science and law, and previously worked as a lawyer and assistant teacher. The move comes after former prime minister K.P. Sharma Oli resigned amid widespread Gen‑Z protests over corruption and a ban on social media, which led to at least 51 deaths. The article states, 'Karki will become the first woman to hold the office of prime minister in the country.' **After Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, Nepal’s Youth Dismisses Its Political Class**
The article reports that on 8 September 2024 a peaceful gathering in Kathmandu turned into an uprising that toppled Nepal’s political elite, leading to the resignation of Prime Minister Khadga Prasad Sharma Oli.  According to the piece, at least 72 people were killed and 2 000 injured, and preliminary estimates put the damage at 2 to 20 billion euros.  The protests destroyed key state buildings – the Parliament, the Supreme Court, ministries, police stations, hotels and the headquarters of *The Kathmandu Post* – and set fire to the historic Singha Durbar complex.  A Ministry of Health employee lamented, ‘I understand that the youth want change, but it is a mess, all the archives go up in smoke,’ while a transport ministry official said, ‘Do not confuse politicians with the buildings that serve the people.’  The unrest was inspired by earlier youth‑led movements in Indonesia, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, and the article notes that the youth of Nepal, often called ‘Nepo‑kids,’ used TikTok and Discord to organize.  After the army imposed a curfew, the youth elected former Supreme Court chief Sushila Karki as prime minister via a Discord vote, a move described as ‘the first government head elected on Discord.’  The article quotes economist Raghu Bir Bista: ‘Beyond the amounts, Generation Z burned symbols. This explosion reflects the feeling that to change the country, one must topple a gangrenous system.’  It also highlights the country’s economic woes – a GDP per capita of 1 447 € (the lowest in South Asia) and youth unemployment above 20 % – and the frustration that drives many to consider emigration.  The piece concludes that the youth’s rapid political mobilisation, though unprecedented, may lead to a new democratic era if the upcoming 2026 elections bring fresh representatives.

**Nepal's interim PM appoints cabinet amid post-protest recovery**
In an effort to stabilize Nepal after deadly anti‑government protests, Prime Minister Sushila Karki, the country’s first female prime minister, appointed an interim cabinet on Monday.  The new ministers—Kalman Gurung as energy minister, Rameshore Khanal as finance minister, and Om Prakash Aryal as home minister—were sworn in outside a government building that had been attacked and set ablaze by protesters the week before.  The appointments come after violent demonstrations sparked by a brief social media ban and widespread anger over corruption that resulted in at least 72 deaths and hundreds of injuries, leading to the collapse of the previous administration.  Karki, 73, who was appointed on September 12, took office following an agreement with leaders of the largely youth‑led ‘Gen Z’ protest movement.  The military, which enforced a curfew during the unrest, ultimately consented to her leadership of a caretaker government charged with overseeing elections within six months.  At a conference on Sunday, Karki stated, 'What we need now is to work to end corruption, bring about good governance, and achieve economic equality. This is what the people truly desire at this moment.'  Businessman Shrawan Dahl expressed confidence in her ability to lead, saying, 'Her objective is to conduct the election, and we hope she will accomplish this task successfully.'

On Monday, Nepal President Ramchandra Paudel administered the oath of office to three ministers appointed by caretaker Prime Minister Sushila Karki, the country’s first woman prime minister. Karki, 73, assumed office on Sunday. The ministers sworn in were Kulman Ghising, Rameshwor Khanal and Om Prakash Aryal. Khanal became Finance Minister; Ghising took charge of energy, water resources and irrigation, physical infrastructure and transport, and urban development; Aryal was appointed Minister for Home Affairs and for Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs. The swearing‑in ceremony was held at the President’s Office, Sheetal Niwas, Maharjgunj. Karki was appointed prime minister at the recommendation of the agitating 'Gen Z' group, which demanded a caretaker government to hold fresh elections on March 5 2026. She took oath on September 12, ending a period of political uncertainty after former prime minister K P Sharma Oli resigned following widespread anti‑government protests led by the same 'Gen Z' group over a ban on social media and alleged corruption. The protests resulted in at least 72 deaths nationwide.

**'Gen Z' protests: What's next for Nepal?**
Thousands of demonstrators in Nepal marched to demand the lifting of a social‑media ban that sparked a wave of anti‑corruption protests and led to the resignation of the prime minister on Tuesday. The protests, which have already claimed at least 19 lives, are dominated by Generation Z (born 1997‑2012) and lack a single leader. The army has called for talks, but it is unclear whom the government can negotiate with. Constitutional expert Balaram KC said, 'Gen Z should set up a negotiation team,' and added that the president should then hold talks with that team, civil‑society members and the army. Under Nepal’s 2015 constitution a successor must be chosen from the party with a parliamentary majority; if none exists the president appoints a candidate who can secure a majority and must win a confidence vote within 30 days. If that fails, the house may be dissolved and elections held. Experts such as Bipin Adhikari propose a temporary interim government that could pursue the reforms demanded by Gen Z and hold elections within six months. Potential leaders favored by the youth include Balendra Shah, the 35‑year‑old mayor of Kathmandu elected in 2022, and Rabi Lamichhane, a former TV journalist who founded the Rastriya Swatantra Party in 2022 and was reportedly freed from prison by protesters. The protesters also want a new constitution; while the 2015 charter allows amendments, they would need parliamentary approval.

**Indians Stranded In Kathmandu As Nepal Remains On The Boil**
Violence erupted across Nepal on Tuesday, even after the resignation of President Ramchandra Paudel, Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli and three ministers. Demonstrators set fire to the Parliament, the President's Office, the PM's residence, the Supreme Court, political party offices and homes of senior leaders. At least 19 people were killed in Monday's protests by Gen Z over corruption and a government ban on social media, which was lifted Monday night. A mob set a house belonging to former prime minister Jhala Nath Khanal on fire in Dallu; his wife Rajyalaxmi Chitrakar sustained serious burn injuries and later died at Kirtipur Burn Hospital. The Supreme Court building, Singhdurbar, the President's Office at Maharajgunj and the PM's residence at Baluwatar were also set ablaze. The Kantipur Television office in Tinkune, as well as police posts at Gaushala, Lubhu and Kalimati, were vandalised and set on fire. The house of former prime minister and Nepali Congress chief Sher Bahadur Deuba in Budhanilkantha was also torched. Kathmandu Metropolitan City Mayor Balen Shah urged calm and called for talks with the Army chief, but insisted Parliament must be dissolved first. Rastriya Swatantra Party chairman Rabi Lamichhane was released from jail; a party leader said, 'Since the administration said they could not provide security and asked the family to take responsibility, his family took charge,' according to My Republica. Meanwhile, a few Telugu families of Indian origin were stranded in Kathmandu; they had been staying at a top hotel but were moved to a nearby guest house after agitators knocked on the doors. An official from Andhra Pradesh Bhavan said, 'We are in constant touch with the Embassy of India in Kathmandu and coordinating through local representatives to safeguard the welfare of these families.'

**Nepal Protests: Buzz Over Oli's Successor Builds, But No Clarity On Frontrunners**
Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli resigned on Tuesday after violent protests that killed 19 people and targeted his residence. The protests were sparked by a ban on 26 social media apps, including Instagram, Facebook and X. The violence also saw the burning of Oli’s home in Bhaktapur and stone‑throwing at the residences of Deputy Prime Minister Bishnu Paudel and Nepal Rastra Bank Governor Biswo Paudel. In the same week, 21 MPs from Rabi Lamichhane’s Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP) resigned, heightening the political crisis. Lamichhane, a former home minister and media personality, is seen as a potential successor, but his ability to lead depends on his release from jail. Another possible contender is Balendra “Balen” Shah, the independent Mayor of Kathmandu, who has publicly supported the Gen‑Z protests and urged that the movement remain non‑partisan. The situation remains volatile, with sources saying clarity may emerge in the next 24–48 hours. The article cites a quote from Shah: 'The rally is clearly a spontaneous movement of Gen‑Z... summary: All seven experts assign an extremely low probability—ranging from 1% to 3%—that Rabi Lamichhane will become the next non-caretaker prime minister of Nepal before January 1, 2026. Their consensus is founded on several core factors: (1) Lamichhane's recent or ongoing legal troubles (generally described as being 'behind bars' for embezzlement), which create strong constitutional and practical eligibility barriers. (2) The explicit caretaker/interim mandate of current Prime Minister Sushila Karki, who is supported by the political elite, military, and international actors to maintain stability and conduct elections by March 2026. (3) The lack of institutional, elite, or coalition support for Lamichhane, with his outsider, divisive status, and his limited party's seat share making coalition-building for a confidence vote nearly impossible. (4) Strong international and domestic incentives for a technocratic, consensus caretaker government until elections, barring a total collapse or spectacular crisis. (5) Historical and regional base rates that show vanishingly few instances of recently-imprisoned, controversial outsider figures rising immediately to executive power under such highly constrained, post-uprising conditions. While all experts note the unpredictable volatility following the Gen Z-led protests and Lamichhane's undeniable youth appeal, they concur that the dominant forces—elite resistance, strict legal hurdles, a clear procedural status quo, and international pressure for stability—heavily outweigh the prospects for an extraordinary, rapid-outlier breakthrough. Only a complete caretaker government collapse combined with legal exoneration, party system paralysis, and a unique elite-protest consensus could plausibly deliver a Yes outcome, which all agree is extremely improbable within the resolution window.
